Description: Linen bag containing cumin seeds (Cuminum cyminum), fragmented coriander seeds (Coriandrum sativum), tiny fragments of papyrus sedge (Cyperus papyrus) stems and leaves, and minute particles of date palm (Arecaceae family) leaves.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: John de Monins Johnson
Curator's comments: Cartwright 2011. Cumin and coriander were both popular cooking spices with a documented history of use in Egypt from as early as the New Kingdom (Murray 200, 643–44). Cartwright, C. R. 2011. Identification of the contents of three linen bags from El-Sheikh Ibada, Egypt. British Museum CSR Analytical Request report 2011/54. [Unpublished]. London. Murray, M. A. 2000. Fruits, vegetables, pulses and condiments. In Ancient Egyptian materials and technologies, P. T. Nicholson and I. Shaw (eds), 609–55. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
Bibliographic references: O'Connell et al 2014 / Antinoupolis at the British Museum (45)
